PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: Mrs. W.S. de Balmhard
Address: 44 Gladstone Ave., Yorkton, Sask.
Birthplace: Ontario

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1902
Where did you set up housekeeping? On a farm, 6 miles off highway
Where had you been living before that? In Yorkton town
For how many people did you prepare meals? 4
How far was it to your nearest store? 6 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Once a week
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Flour, sugar, tea, coffee, cocoa, syrup, rice, cornmeal, vanilla, pickles (cured, not salted)

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Local mill flour
In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lbs.
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.50
How much did you use graham flour? None
Whole wheat flour? None
Was flour milled locally? Yes
How far away? 6 miles
What other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal? None
Whole Wheat? None
Farina? None
Other? None
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
How did you grind it? None

Name: Mrs. W.S. de Balinhard

Address: 44 Gladstone Ave., Yorkton, Sask.

Birthplace: Ontario

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping? 1902

Where did you set up housekeeping? Yorkton, Sask.

Where had you been living before that? Ontario

For how many years did you live there? 6 months

How far was it to your nearest store? 1 mile

How often could a visit be made to the store? Once a week

What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Flour, sugar, salt, tea, coffee, corn meal, flour

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand or white flour did you use in the early years? White flour

In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lbs.

What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $3.00

How much did you use Graham flour? 50 lbs.

Whole wheat flour? 50 lbs.

Was flour milled locally? Yes

What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? $1.50

What other grain products did you use? Cornmeal

Other? Whole Wheat

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No

How did you grind it? Hand mill
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 10 lbs.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? 50¢

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? 5 lbs.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 48¢

At what price?

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days?

Butter? How much at a time? Half a pint, three.

That was the price of butter? 25¢

Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes, how? We used to keep them in a box with sawdust, used a solution of lime and salt in a box only enough to keep them eggs.

Did you make butter? Yes, cheese?

What kind of cheese?

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Beef, pork, fish.

How did you get fresh meat? From the Butcher shop.

How often did you get fresh meat? Once a week.

How did you preserve meat? We bought cured hams and bacon.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Yes.

If so what year was it organized?

Did you use game? Yes, what kinds? Pheasants, ducks, Geese, Cranes, Marmots, Rabbits.

For how long? During the summer.

What part did fish play in the family diet? Quarters or half.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh.

Kinds? Jack fish, snad, white fish, bass, trout.
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? Blue Ribbon but what price? 3 lbs. for $1.50
What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Aroma
Price? 25¢/lb... What other beverages were used? None

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping?
$1.50/bushel Could you get potatoes at the store? Yes
If not, where from? Tennessee
What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of? 1902
Potatoes Yes... Cabbage Yes... Carrots Yes... Onions Yes...
Turnips Yes... Beets Yes...
In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? 25¢ at a time
How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? 5¢
What weight? ............ How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)?
......................... What was the price of prunes? 10¢/lb
What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)?

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? Peas? Yes... Corn? Beans? Saskatoon? Yes...
Other foods? .........................................
What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1902
What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 1902
What year did you first preserve meat by canning? 1902
Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Yes
To what extent? About 200 quarts of preserved foods
Did you make your own vinegar? Yes
We bought a substance called "Mother of Vinegar" put it in a keg and added all our cold tea to it. In about 3 weeks we had a real good vinegar like malt vinegar.

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, slough, dugout) ..................................................................

How far was this water from your home? ...................................................

How was it brought to the house? (pail, barrel, tank) ...........................................

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

Moved to town 1913 carried water for week
In 1928 had water put in house but other places in Goblin had modern houses
14 years before
22. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, cistern, dugout) ... W.E.B.

If or for was this water from your house? ... No, yard tank.

If or for was this water from the house? (Well, barrel, tank)

How was it brought to the house? (Well, barrel, tank)

For existing water supply mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

First started housekeeping in 1913, owned well for week, then father moved to town in 1918, had water put in house, then moved to town in third year before.

Please note: Year before...
13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Both

If you made your own, did you use lye? Yes... wood ashes?

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? Royal Crown bar

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Wood

Where did you get your fuel? From the woods, from the creek, from the riverbank.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

In 1910 we started burning coal for heating, and wood for cooking and still do.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates)

By whom was your first cook stove made? J. Murray

What year was it purchased? 1920

Price? $8.00

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) Iron, Tin

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) Earthenware

When did you first see enamel ware? 1920

Aluminum? I got my first aluminum in 1913

16. **Wrappings and Containers**

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

In 1902 everything came to the store in bulk and had to be weighed out.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the date and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

When I was a child of 8 breakfast oatmeal porridge, milk toast and warm apple and coffee.

Dinner: meat potatoes, kind of vegetable, pea pudding, bread butter tea, milk.

Supper: fried potatoes, eggs, fruit, cake, tea, a milk, bread, butter.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Eastern Canada? Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

Christmas 1902, dinner: roast beef, plum pudding, with hard sauce, potatoes, turnips, beef pickles, cranberry sauce, bread, butter, tea.

There were 5 of us, my husband, his mother, his young son, and a hired man and myself.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

Once when a child of 8 we ran out of flour and Mother cooked wheat by boiling it and we had Johnny cake made out of corn meal and I hate the stuff yet. Nothing can take the place of bread, we had potatoes, but no sugar we also had barley roasted and made into coffee. We had a big bag of syrup and salt pork.
Once when a child of 8 we knew not how to
flour any other cooked wheat

For many years I cooked John's cake
for him. I made our own meal and I hate the
stuff yet. Sometimes we had it three times a day.

We also had barley watered and mixed into
the milk.

so convenient with all the modern conveniences and food already for cooking
